I'm frightened of not coming back in one piece. Much more than dying. I wouldn't know what to do with myself in a wheel chair. And I couldn't stand to be pitied.
There's a Church near our house. Next to the pub. Every night at ten the drunks spill out, shouting at the top of their voices. That's where I want to be buried. Where I can hear them.

...Field Marshall Willoughby...

-- Please hear me out...

You smell wonderful.
Ethne...?
Ethne...?

Replies.Reply: These past few days have been the best days of my life, blind or otherwise...

...Before I came here I'd given up. I put on all kinds of fronts and defences, but deep down I was petrified. I had no idea what was going on around me, what people were thinking behind my back. I imagined the worst, so that nothing would surprise me, no-one would catch me out...

...You've made me realise I can't live like that. Whether one can see or not, there's no way of knowing how people really feel about you, all you can do is put yourself in their hands, and trust them unconditionally...
I know how much you loved Harry...
...for the first time I'm not afraid to admit it, I'm not not afraid to bring it up between us...
I'm not afraid, because of you Ethne, because of the way you've made me feel...
Ethne...?
Ethne...?
I thought you'd disappeared.
I'm sorry.
She was here a minute ago. It must have been something I said.
Willoughby?...
Willoughby was here? Why didn't he come and see me?
...Harry...
Ethne obviously didn't want me to know...
Why did you tell me?
You're her friend.
You're not fair to Ethne.
How much of our conversation did you overhear?
Then you should know I meant every word.
I love and trust Ethne unconditionally. Whatever doubts she's feeling, I know she'll resolve them.
I've put myself in her hands.
I'm sorry, Mrs Adair.
Come in.
How did you know?
Scotch alright?
I've got to cut down on the stuff. I'm putting on weight. hARRY You look good.
Not as good as you, I'm sure.
I heard Ethne's carriage outside?
Why didn't she come up?
Do we need a few minutes alone? Even though he's smiling, the air is thick with tension.
For what? hARRY For standing by me.
If you're talking about the feathers, I wasn't there.
You don't owe me anything Harry. The wedding isn't for another month. Ethne's free to make up her own mind.
Have another one.
Please.
The friendship was the best thing about that place. It's the one thing I haven't been able to hang onto. It's his way of asking Harry to stay. HARRY sits again.
I've become like one of those old soldiers we used to laugh at. Forcing my stories on everyone. Enough medals on my uniform to light up a Christmas tree.
Have they given you back your commission?
I suppose it wouldn't be the British Army if they admitted their mistakes.
To Castelton and all the others we left behind.
You did everything you could.
You saw it happen?
Except my own.
It's hard to talk like this with anyone else. They all want to know how many people you've killed, but the moment you mention the friends you've lost, their eyes glaze over.
No.
Do you ever miss the desert Harry?
Maybe we should change places.
You remember the first time we led a cavalry charge in public?
Ethne was watching.
That's right.
We'd met her the previous night, at the regimental ball.
You should. You were the only one she danced with.
I've never been so jealous. I stayed up all night brooding. The next day I was determined to show you up -- prove to her I was the better soldier.
And it still didn't make a difference.
She was the first person I looked for in the crowd, and she was staring at you. Everyone else was applauding me, and she was staring at you.
I'm not sure if anything's changed.
To us Harry.
To you.
...Idiot.
Ask me that when we're in Bombay.
Your sole purpose in life is to annoy me.
I could see you. I can see you everywhere I look. Pulling those stupid faces at me.
I think we should give Harry a chance to explain.
Harry's gone. He left this morning. Whilst you were all asleep.
Sniper!
It's only a scratch.
Shut up Trench...
Are you alright, Jack?
I'll go.
Harry?

Take these back!

On what?

It isn't stopping.

That must be him.
It isn't true then, you can see...
I hardly made a noise.
Let me get you some tea, and then we can talk.
Bound by what?
You're not a different man.
Jack --
Why does it have to be without me?
If you don't know how I feel about you, then that's a good reason to call off our wedding. Your blindness isn't.
He seems to need his eyes less and less each day. It's incredible. Nothing escapes him. Sometimes I think he reads me like a book.
And you smell like a horse. Go wash.
...Someone to see you Miss Eustace.
What do you want, Tom?
Is Harry dead?
Changed how?
Tell me everything Tom. Please...
If by your own admission you've hurt me, then I have a right to know.
I should have been proud of him before. Or at least I should have tried to understand. willoughby You can't blame yourself.

Please, I don't want him to know you're here.

-- I'm engaged to Jack. I'm going to marry him.

-- Please, tell me the truth.

Who could that be...
The Melusine overture.
I'd rather listen.

I want to hear you play on your own.
Don't worry about the biscuits General.
He'll be pleased to hear that. gENERAL FEVERSHAM I'm very fond of the boy.
Have you heard any news from the Sudan?
I'm sure it doesn't mean anything.
I'm not sure I could cope right now.
Have you looked at them?
You must be very proud.
We all misjudged him.
Everyone said how much you'd changed. I didn't believe them.

That isn't what he told me.
May I have it back?
I'd still like it back.
I have three of them, I'd like four.

I'm glad you did what you did, on your own, without anyone's help. I'm glad for you, Harry.
You've heard our news?...
You'd laugh if I told you.
I was thinking I'd get up and leave when that patch of sunlight disappeared. So far it's been quite resilient.
I passed by your appartment the other day.
When?
When you didn't come and see me...

Because I love you Harry...and I can't. I can't.
I'll take you to the station.

I'd love to dance.
